lessons.title: Lesson #1
lessons.interactiveContent:
Use object destructuring to extract properties from an object.

Make sure to pick const followed by { and then title, author, }, =, book, ;.

lessons.title: Lesson #1 - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Complete the code using the destructured object.

Make sure to pick title, followed by director.

lessons.title: Lesson #3
lessons.interactiveContent:
Apply destructuring for the dish property.

Make sure to type props.dish.

lessons.title: Lesson #1
lessons.interactiveContent:
Render the Profile component with a fallback for the rank property to display "No Rank" if not provided.

Make sure to pick props.rank, followed by props.rank, and finally "No Rank".

lessons.title: Lesson #2
lessons.interactiveContent:
What is the expected output when the property rank is not provided in the Profile component?

Rank: UnrankedRank: RankedRank: NoneRank: Undefined

Rank: Unranked.

lessons.title: Lesson #1
lessons.interactiveContent:
Set a default value of "Traveler" for the username property using destructuring.

Make sure to pick { followed by username and then =, "Traveler", }.

lessons.title: Lesson #2
lessons.interactiveContent:
What will the following code display? Check if the default parameter needs to be used.

Hello, VisitorHello, MaverickundefinedHello, Guest

Hello, Visitor.

lessons.title: Lesson #1
lessons.interactiveContent:
Render a list in React with data from a JavaScript array and use index as the key.

Make sure to pick movies followed by .map and then index, movie.

lessons.title: Lesson #3
lessons.interactiveContent:
What does the following code display on the screen?

No list at all because an empty array is passedAn array with two itemsAn array with three itemsAn error occurs

No list at all because an empty array is passed.

lessons.title: Lesson #1
lessons.interactiveContent:
Create a React component that displays a list of your favorite songs using an array as the state variable.

Make sure to pick songs followed by . and then map, song, index, index, song.

lessons.title: Lesson #3
lessons.interactiveContent:
Create a textarea and update its value dynamically.

Make sure to pick < followed by textarea and then onChange, =, {, handleChange, }, /, >.

lessons.title: Lesson #3
lessons.interactiveContent:
Implement a controlled text area.

Make sure to pick description followed by setDescription and then useState, description.

lessons.title: Lesson #4
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which of these is a correct way to destructure an object?

const { name, price } = propsconst name,price = propsconst name = props.name, price = props.priceconst [name, price] = props

const { name, price } = props.

lessons.title: Lesson #5
lessons.interactiveContent:
Extract and use the title property. in a movie component.

Make sure to pick { followed by title and then }, {, title, }.

lessons.title: Lesson #3
lessons.interactiveContent:
Capture user input and convert it to uppercase before displaying it.

Make sure to pick event followed by .target and then .value, .toUpperCase().

lessons.title: Lesson #3
lessons.interactiveContent:
Implement a default value for the status property in the Profile component.

Make sure to pick { followed by props.status and then ?, props.status, :, "Offline", }.

lessons.title: Lesson #3
lessons.interactiveContent:
Set a default value of "Sunshine" for the weather property using destructuring and use an embedded expression to display it.

Make sure to pick weather followed by = and then "Sunshine", {, weather, }.

lessons.title: Lesson #3
lessons.interactiveContent:
Complete the code to correctly display a list of book titles.

Make sure to pick <li followed by key and then =, {, index, }, >, </li>.

lessons.title: Lesson #4
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which method is used to iterate through an array in React to render elements?

mapforEachfilterreduce

Make sure to pick map.

lessons.title: Lesson #3
lessons.interactiveContent:
Create an ordered JSX list of superhero names using the index as the key.

Make sure to pick index followed by key= and then {, index, }.

lessons.title: Lesson #1
lessons.interactiveContent:
Store the input in a state variable.

Make sure to type setMessage.

lessons.title: Lesson #2
lessons.interactiveContent:
What's the length of the property items?

0123

Make sure to pick 0.

lessons.title: Lesson #1
lessons.interactiveContent:
Create a controlled component using a dropdown to select a color.

Make sure to type value.

lessons.title: Lesson #5
lessons.interactiveContent:
Create a controlled component with a checkbox.

Make sure to pick checked.

lessons.title: Lesson #1
lessons.interactiveContent:
Complete the code so that it uses the index as the key for the list items correctly.

Make sure to type key={index}.

lessons.title: Lesson #2
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which of the following statements about using the key property in React lists is true?

Keys help React identify which items have changedKeys should be a random value each timeKeys can be omitted if items are uniqueKeys should always be numerical

Keys help React identify which items have changed.

lessons.title: Lesson #4
lessons.interactiveContent:
What is the benefit of using default property values in a React component?

To ensure components render with a fallback value when a property is missingTo make properties required at all timesTo prevent any values from being passed to componentsTo make the component private

To ensure components render with a fallback value when a property is missing.

lessons.title: Lesson #1
lessons.interactiveContent:
How do we render array elements conditionally in React when using the map method?

Using inline if-else statements or ternary operatorsUsing filter method onlyOnly JavaScript built-in functionsUsing the forEach loop

Using inline if-else statements or ternary operators.

lessons.title: Lesson #2
lessons.interactiveContent:
Create a React component that renders a list of movies with proper formatting.

Make sure to pick movies followed by . and then map, movie.

lessons.title: Lesson #2
lessons.interactiveContent:
What is the result of rendering this React component?

A header and a list with red, green, and blueA header and a list without itemsA list with red, green, and blueAn error

A header and a list with red, green, and blue.

lessons.title: Lesson #1
lessons.interactiveContent:
Create an input field and print a message as the user types.

Make sure to pick handleChange followed by setMessage and then input, handleChange, message.

lessons.title: Lesson #2
lessons.interactiveContent:
What will be the output when an input event happens in the following code?

It logs the current input valueIt logs undefinedIt logs the placeholder textIt logs a static string

It logs the current input value.

lessons.title: Lesson #6
lessons.interactiveContent:
What is true about destructuring props in React functional components?

It makes the code cleaner and easier to read by directly using the property namesIt makes components slower by adding more syntaxIt can only be used with class componentsIt removes props from the component

It makes the code cleaner and easier to read by directly using the property names.

lessons.title: Lesson #2
lessons.interactiveContent:
What is the purpose of the placeholder attribute in a textarea element?

It provides a hint to the user about what to enter in the textareaIt styles the textareaIt sets the textarea background colorIt determines the maximum number of characters

It provides a hint to the user about what to enter in the textarea.

lessons.title: Lesson #3
lessons.interactiveContent:
Create a function to update state variable friends by adding a new friend, "John", to the list.

Make sure to pick const followed by addFriend and then (, ), {, setFriends, ...friends, "John", }.

lessons.title: Lesson #2
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which of the following statements regarding controlled components is true?

Controlled components have their state managed by ReactControlled components manage their own state internallyControlled components do not re-render when state changesControlled components cannot use the onChange event

Controlled components have their state managed by React.
